description: From Middle English dede, from Old English dēd, dǣd (“deed, act”), from Proto-West Germanic *dādi, from Proto-Germanic *dēdiz (“deed”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰéh₁tis (“deed, action”). Analyzable through Proto-Germanic as do +‎ -th. Doublet of thesis.

entries.meaning: An action or act; something that is done.
examples: One small deed can have one stour effect or more.

entries.meaning: A brave or noteworthy action; a feat or exploit.
Action or fact, as opposed to rhetoric or deliberation.
examples: I have fulfilled my promise in word and in deed.

entries.meaning: (law) A legal instrument that is executed under seal or before witnesses.
examples: I inherited the deed to the house.

verbs.description: deed (third-person singular simple present deeds, present participle deeding, simple past and past participle deeded)

entries.meaning: (informal) To transfer real property by deed.
examples: He deeded over the mineral rights to some fellas from Denver.
